pull in.translation[0].definitions[0].de: if a driver pulls in, they move to the side of the road and stop
pull in.translation[0].definitions[0].ex: She pulled in to let the ambulance pass.
pull in.translation[0].definitions[1].de: if a train pulls in, it arrives at a station
pull in.translation[0].definitions[2].de: to attract business, money, people etc
pull in.translation[0].definitions[2].ex: a publicity stunt to pull in the crowds
pull in.translation[0].definitions[3].de: if you pull in a lot of money, you earn it
pull in.translation[0].definitions[4].de: if a police officer pulls someone in, they take them to a police station because they think that person may have done something wrong
pull in.translation[1].definitions[0].de: to earn a large amount of money
pull in.translation[1].definitions[0].ex: Within a short time, the business was pulling in over $10 million a year.
The government expects to pull in around Â£1 billion from the new tax.
pull in.translation[1].definitions[1].de: if an event pulls in a lot of people, they go to it
pull in.translation[1].definitions[1].ex: The show has been pulling in huge crowds in New York.
